messageBody:
You just write down the sentences as you pronounce them, no need to
hassle with 'official' forms.

I first learned myself Shavian which took about 1 to 2 weeks, and
learning Quikscript took me about one week of practice. All I did was
starting a small dairy and write down my thoughts which took me about
a hour or a hour and a half each day. I also used it during meetings
which boosted my writing skills. Biggest problem in the beginning may
be reading your notes back fast. Just write down whatever you like and
read your own writings back, that's the best practice.

Ramses

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "oliver langan" <oliver@...> wrote:
>
> > How does
> > Quikscript allow for the ever-changing pronunciation of English as it
> > evolves over time (and across borders)? Is the spelling of words
> > changed merely based upon who is saying them?
> >
> > Also, about shapes of the glyphs themselves, they don't appear to flow
> > nicely from one to the next. I'm wondering why some "natural"
> > alphabet, such as Arabic, has not been retrofitted to English if a
> > quick and flowing way to write is the intended goal?
>
> Actually, I think that Quickscript as originally designed by Read
> handles both of these issues quite well. After he had already won the
> contest to produce an alternate alphabet (resulting in Shavian), he
> must have gotten quite a lot of feedback about its spelling as
> presented in Androcles and the Lion. Shavian was meant to reproduce
> the English "that recorded "of His Majesty our late King George V"
> (per Shaw's instruction), and no doubt this raise the hackles of
> people in other parts of the English speaking world. Moreover, during
> its development, it is clear that Quickscript was 'test marketed' with
> correspondents from around the globe.
>
> The result, as Tim mentioned, is that a great many of the vowel sounds
> that have shifted from one accent to the next have actually been
> omitted from Quickscript, usually through standard abbreviations.
> This also nicely handles words in which the pronunciation changes by
> grammatical rule, as with the in "the book" vs. "the onion."
>
> As for the glyph shapes, Read consciously tried to make the
> connections between the characters either flowing (as from Utter to
> Roe in "array") or acute (as from Why to Et in "when"). This seems to
> match, in a vague sort of way, habits already learned from English
> handwriting... but I must admit my handwriting is atrocious and I tend
> to type everything. The real savings for me, I think, is in the
> frequent contractions and abbreviations. "This is the way to do it",
> on the front of the manual, is only 7 letters!
>
> (I know I keep promising this, but really, I will upload the re-worked
> Kingsley font soon. I only regret that Windows does not seem to
> support the kerning for all the letters: so much effort down the tubes.)
>
> oliver
>
